notes: Final years of first-generation Mustang with multiple performance variants including Mach 1 and Boss 351. Grande trim offered luxury features. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Mustang (first generation) article, September 1970 revision.
Coke bottle styling with increased dimensions. GT and Cobra performance packages available. Wheelbase 117.0 inches. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Torino article, model years 1970-1971.

Full-size sedan with squared-off rooflines from 1971. Convertible discontinued after 1972. XL model ended 1970. Final year 1974 before nameplate discontinued. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Galaxie article, latest revision.

Full-size luxury sedan. Convertible available 1971-1972. Hidden headlamps removed in 1971. Wheelbase 121.0 inches. Country Squire wagon variant available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford LTD (Americas) article, specifications for 1970-1979.

Body-on-frame chassis with distinctive bird's beak grille projection. Sequential turn signals in full panel tail lights. Wheelbase 115 inches (2-door) and 117.2 inches (4-door landau). Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Thunderbird (fifth generation) article, October 11, 2025 revision.

Body-on-frame chassis. 460 V8 became standard from 1974. Wheelbase 120.4 inches, length 225 inches. Curb weight approximately 5,000 lbs. Assembled in Wixom, Michigan and Pico Rivera, California. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Thunderbird (sixth generation) article, August 9, 2025 revision.

Compact car marketed as simple and economical. 4-door sedan introduced 1971. 302 V8 added mid-1971. Wheelbase 103 inches (2-door) and 109.9 inches (4-door). Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Maverick (Americas) article, June 8, 2025 revision.

Subcompact economy car with rear-engine, rear-wheel-drive layout. Wheelbase 94.0 inches. 2.3L I4 introduced 1974, 2.8L V6 introduced 1975. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Pinto article, July 1980 revision.

Switched to body-on-frame construction in 1972. 5 mph bumper standards added 1973. Gran Torino Elite introduced 1974. SportsRoof discontinued after 1974. 460 V8 available in Police package only. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Torino article, 2023 revision.
Coupe utility pickup based on Torino platform. Wheelbase 114.0 inches. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Ranchero article, October 4, 2025 revision.

Coupe utility pickup based on Gran Torino platform. Wheelbase 118.0 inches, length 215.7 inches. 429 V8 available 1972-1973, 460 V8 available 1974-1976. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Ranchero article, October 4, 2025 revision.
Final generation coupe utility pickup based on LTD II platform. Length 220.1 inches. Production ended 1979. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Ranchero article, October 4, 2025 revision.

Compact pickup imported from Mazda B-series platform. Load capacity 1,400 lbs. 5-speed manual introduced 1976. Base engine increased to 2.0L in 1979. Optional Ford-built 2.3L engine same as Pinto and Mustang II. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Courier article, September 4, 2025 revision.

Full-size pickup truck. SuperCab extended cab introduced 1974. Available trims: Custom, Ranger, Ranger XLT, Ranger Lariat (1978-1979). Part-time and full-time 4WD options. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford F-Series (sixth generation) article, September 5, 2025 revision.

Compact Mustang redesign. 302 V8 added in 1975 with C4 automatic. Rack and pinion steering, compression strut front suspension. Wheelbase 96.2 inches. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Mustang (second generation) article, September 26, 2025 revision.

Personal luxury coupe. Initially marketed as Gran Torino Elite in 1974, renamed Elite for 1975-1976. Wheelbase 114 inches. Assembled in Chicago, Lorain, and Pico Rivera. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Elite article, August 27, 2025 revision.

Compact sedan with unibody construction. Wheelbase 109.9 inches. Coil-spring front suspension, leaf-sprung live rear axle. Standard 11-inch front disc brakes and 10-inch rear drums, optional 4-wheel disc brakes. 4-speed manual introduced 1976. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Granada (North America) article, July 17, 2025 revision.

First Ford van with body-on-frame construction. Available in 100/150/250/350 variants. Wheelbase options 124 inches and 138 inches. Club Wagon passenger van variant. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Econoline article, 1975 model year introduction.

Full-size SUV based on F-Series platform. Part-time 4WD with New Process 205 gear-driven transfer case standard. Optional permanent 4WD with New Process 203 chain-driven transfer case. Wheelbase 104 inches, curb weight 4,663-4,718 lbs. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Bronco article, latest revision.

Subcompact imported from Europe. Fitted with catalytic converter, air pump, energy-absorbing bumpers, side-marker lamps, and round sealed-beam headlamps for US market. Trim levels: Base, Decor, Sport, Ghia. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Fiesta (first generation) article, September 19, 2025 revision.

Compact sedan on Ford Fox platform with steel unibody construction. Futura coupe introduced late 1978. 4-speed manual available in 1979 for all engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Fairmont article, August 1977 revision.
